conclusion: A basketball of mass m is dropped from rest at a height H and rebounds to a maximum height h.
The magnitude of the gravitational force is mg and the magnitude of the air resistance is λmg, where 0 < λ < (H-h)/(H+h).
The potential energy at height H is mgh and using conservation of energy, the velocity just before hitting the ground (v1) can be calculated as v1 = sqrt(2gH).

Let the post-collision velocity be v2. The basketball rebounds to a maximum height h, so the kinetic energy converts back to potential energy. Using conservation of energy for the rebound, the velocity just after hitting the ground can be expressed as v2 = sqrt(2gh).
The ratio of the post-collision velocity to the pre-collision velocity is Ratio = v2/v1 = sqrt(2gh)/sqrt(2gH) = sqrt(h/H).
The air resistance (λmg) affects the velocities and given that the ratio of the post-collision velocity to the pre-collision velocity remains constant with each collision, it simplifies our analysis.
Thus, the ratio of the post-collision velocity to the pre-collision velocity is sqrt(h/H).
